@ScrubKing pt 3: Short Form ... NETORARE = cuckold-porn. Reader gets to be a cuckold, feels sexually humiliated & ashamed ... NETORASE = cuckolder-porn. Reader gets to be a cuckolder, feels virile & sexually dominant ... NETORI = cheater-porn. Reader gets to be a cheater, feels morally corrupt yet sexually liberated.

@ScrubKing pt 2: To clarify the distinction, let's use this story as an example ..... The unrequited would-be lover here is the *passive* victim of love-theft: the cuckold. Since the reader is invited to share his viewpoint, the reader vicariously becomes the cuckold. This is NETORARE, the passive form of the noun and genre ..... The cousin, meanwhile, is the *active* love-stealer: the cuckolder. If the reader were invited to share his viewpoint, then the reader would get the vicarious experience of cuckolding someone else. This would be NETORASE, the active form of the noun/genre ... The FMC, finally, neither has her love stolen nor steals the love of another. If she were the viewpoint character (and if she had been in a real relationship with the MMC), then the reader would vicariously experience her cuckolding of her partner. This would be NETORI ..... That's why I said earlier that viewpoint is so essential in making these distinctions.

@ScrubKing pt 1: I agree that netorare is not precisely identical to cuckold. Each can be a noun or a verb, and their forms differ in use and meaning. For one thing, cuckold typically applies only to partner loss in formal relationships (originally a man's loss of his wife to another man), while netorare is used more broadly, as in this story and the KC no M example. Nevertheless, cuckold is usually the closest single-word English equivalent .... The key difference between the nouns netorare, netorase and netori lies in the conjugation of the verbs from which they originate, as suggested by the KC no M analysis ..... Netorare is the *passive* form of love-theft, expressed as a noun. In English, this is "to be cuckolded", and the resulting noun is cuckold. Netorase is the *active" form of love-theft as a noun. In English, this is "to cuckold", with the corresponding noun cuckolder. Finally, netori is love-theft in general, and the English equivalent is adultery, or simply cheating.

P.S. Of course, the appeal of netorare-themed pornography extends well beyond the niche of dedicated cuckolding fetishists. In recent years, legions of garden-variety shithead sadists have gravitated to the genre, drawn like moths to flame by the spectacle of human suffering. These pathetic cretins don't really understand netorare and don't care to learn anything about it. They just want to flap their feeble meats while drooling and giggling in the dark. Which is fine. The less they interact with actual human beings, the better. And since netorare is a garbage genre to begin with, nothing of value is lost.

@ScrubKing: No offense, but mooing like a drunk with a dented head doesn't improve the quality of your arguments. It just makes you seem kind of sad. Here's a good breakdown of the terms involved, written by someone with a solid grasp of Japanese language and culture: https://www.japanesewithanime.com/2018/01/netori.html ... Put simply, netorare is the genre of erotica that caters to a cuckolding fetish (the fetish of being cheated on, of having one's beloved "sleep stolen" by someone else) ... But back to the story in question. At issue is not the MMC's understanding of what he sees. The important thing is that the READER understands what he sees. To the netorare-fetishist who identifies with the MMC, the character's witnessing of his own quasi-cuckolding will be sufficient to generate the forbidden thrill.

@ScrubKing: "he sees the from afar but he does not realize they are fucking" --- As I said, the MMC watches them fuck. Whether or not he understands what he's seeing is a separate issue. And netorare doesn't necessarily depend on the loss of a bona-fide spouse, partner, or significant other. Lots of netorare fetish stories concern the quasi-cuckolding of passive would-be lovers with unrequited crushes. The defining feature of the genre is a story structure that encourages the reader to identify WITH the cuckold, to vicariously experience their fetishized sense of betrayal, loss and/or shame. Otherwise, it's just cheating: perhaps netorase, but if not, then simply netori. Here, I agree that the cuckold-identification element is subtle. But it's definitely present. Therefore netorare (or at least "low netorare"). One could perhaps argue that it's netorase, too, but that seems a stretch.

The title both means "after the festival" and "too late". It literally means "after the festival", which is the basis for the idiom "too late"; if you were to show up the day "after the festival", then you missed out on all the fun and were "too late".
